comments.content: what did you select for those 2 tickets?

discussion.content:
For anybody about to take this exam, I had two different tickets to the ones displayed here.
One was regarding a user being unable to access the LAN and the other focused on a user who complained about the lack of internet access, but actually had typed an incorrect URL.

I took this exam today and I had the same issue as silent_siren on here. I was able to pass it still but I believe I got them wrong because I was confused on the scenarios. I forgot what they were about.

I had this EXACT PBQ on my exam this week. Only issue was when I tried to click on Close Ticket at then end it told me to Select a ticket, but there was no way to do so. 
I could never confirm get confirmation that I had closed out the tickets and submitted my answers. I alerted the proctor who didn't know what to do about it, so I just moved on and did the rest of the test. I still had some time left after finishing the multiple choice questions, so I came back to it and tried to close out the tickets again, but still got the same message about needing to select a ticket. 

I ended up passing the exam and according to my results It didn't show me getting this question wrong; so don't stress like I did for 10 minutes if you get this PBQ and it doesn't let you close the ticket out. Also note the answers selected in the drop down menus. They are 100% correct.

For anyone that still needs help with the PBQs, CyberDean has some videos demonstrating similar exam questions
https://www.youtube.com/user/DeanKisyovv/playlists
Can I get a copy of the videos please?
Can I get a copy of the videos also. I test in a week. ThNKS!
Anyone who had just taken this exam, any pointers about PBQ questions to look forward on the exam.I'm taking the exam in two weeks time.Thanks

The BSOD is driver related, but not quite sure as to what Comptia wants.

questions.question_text:
As part of a CYOD policy, a systems administrator needs to configure each user's Windows device to require a password when resuming from a period of sleep or inactivity.
Which of the following paths will lead the administrator to the correct settings?

discussion.content: I noticed that almost every time if the question has FIRST, the answer will be "Check" or "Look up" :))

comments.content: Yes. Rarely is taking action the FIRST thing you do. You have to ID/verify all angles of the problem first.
thanks 4 this observation

discussion.content: B is the most appropriate answer because most modern mobile OS's will allow you to check which apps have permissions to phone functions, including the camera. It's possible an installed app has permissions to the camera which could be causing the forementioned problems. It would also be the fastest and least damaging step you could take in this scenario.
Hi everyone
Sorry guys, are all these answers officially correct answers or they are just based on what we think?

B - Permissions. The phone has been hacked and the permissions need to be checked to see if the hacker has access to your camera. Since its making a sound and no pics are on your phone the hacker is taking pics and uploading to his/her computer.
B is correct. CompTIA would also claim B to be correct. Read the question carefully.

"steps should be taken FIRST to determine the cause of the issue?"
 This is the only answer that can determine the cause. All others are actions to fix an issue.
 This answer has to be correct as it is the only one that might let you know the problem.

There is a similar question in eh beginning of the exam that references two android phones that are experiencing identical issues with the same app and the answer calls for an OS update. Seems odd that this answer has you performing some basic troubleshooting.
B is not the answer, E is. If an app were permitted to use the camera, the tech would have discovered the photos in the album. The software update, E, is a much more reasonable place to begin.

comments.content: so you're telling me I can't create a malicious app that takes photos from your phone's camera and uploads them to my drive in the cloud without saving the photo in your device's photo album?
exactly! I read the question and my mind immediately went to "you're being spied, check permissions"
yes, and because you can now see the list of apps that have camera permissions on. It could be dozens of them and a new update may not help with malware

According to David L. Prowse as mentioned in his book CompTIA A+ Core 1 (220-1001) and Core 2 (220-1002) Exam Cram: "It could be that another program (quite possibly malicious) is using the camera on its own without user intervention. So, the first best thing to do is to check the application permissions. For example, in Android a typical navigational path would be General > Apps & Notifications > App permissions. From there you will see the Camera app; tap it to find out which applications are using it. Then, you can deselect whichever apps you need to. You might also find a malicious or unwanted program is on the list and enabled for camera usage–if so, it should be removed."

discussion.content: Is it B or E?

Yes, it is because an App Permissions menu does not constitute any evidence for what is happening in this scenario. In an App Permissions menu, you'd normally see something along the lines of, i.e., "Allowed: Camera, Microphone, Storage, Location, etc." If not allowed, then, for instance, the camera application wouldn't even work. Given the question, this wouldn't have anything to do with a smartphone's camera shutter noise "bugging" out, and with no saved images. Therefore, it'd have to be how the application interacts with the OS, for that's what controls how the camera application operates in the first place.

comments.content: you may be right about everything but comptia wants you to check first before you do anything such as updating deleting or modifying thats why I think it could be B in this case because its the "first" thing you should do even thou its not going to fix anything.
I think you are right, checking and verifying if anything is out of the ordinary is the first step with comptia troubleshooting.

To specify even further, the FIRST thing a technician would do wouldn't be to check permissions, because you already have been given the necessary information you need to deduce that App Permissions isn't an issue. The camera application is installed on their phone; on every phone by default. Also, it isn't a matter of, "Why isn't my camera application working?", but more so, "Why is my camera application bugging out?"
Why would an OS update resolve an issue associated with one specific app? It rarely would, if at all. The app's permissions are more likely the cause.
Is there a reason you believe the answer should be E?

discussion.content: E is the correct answer, not B.

questions.question_text:
A user's smartphone is making the camera shutter noise even when the user is not taking pictures. When the user opens the photo album, there are no new pictures.
Which of the following steps should be taken FIRST to determine the cause of the issue?

choices.C: Reset the phone to factory settings
choices.D: Update all of the applications on the phone

discussion.content:
Multi-factor= something that you have and something that you know.
Single factor= password and username.. Both are things that you know

Single-factor authentication is the simplest form of authentication methods. With SFA, a person matches one credential to verify himself or herself online. The most popular example of this would be a password (credential) to a username. Most verification today uses this type of authentication method.

comments.content: It is single factor because the user is using just his username and password for authentication, and RADIUS and TACAS servers are used for multi factor authentications.
radius can be used for both mode and others type of connection

discussion.content: Why not RADIUS ?

questions.question_text:
Joe, an end user, has been prompted to provide his username and password to access the payroll system.
Which of the following authentication methods is being requested?
